catalog_description: Introduction to computer programming using a C family language. Students with no previous programming experience in C++ will learn computer organization and operation, binary representation of information, how to plan and create well-structured programs, write programs using sequence, selection and repetition structures, and create and manipulate sequential access files, structs, classes, pointers and arrays.
recommended_preparation: “C” grade or higher or “Pass” in CS 119 or equivalent, and intermediate algebra
entrance_skills: Demonstrate knowledge of software engineering methodologies and practices.
Identify common tools, functions, classes and utilities available in modern programming languages.
Define and utilize structured programming principles.
Design “behaviors” that follow all structured programming guidelines.
Utilize the three basic logic control structures of sequence, decision and repetition.
Conceptualize abstraction, polymorphism, inheritance and encapsulation.
Trace the flow of execution and values of all variables through a complex object-oriented program.
course_content: Introduction to Computers, the Internet, and the Web
Structured Program Development in C: Algorithms, Pseudocode, If, While, Operators
Functions: Modules, Libraries, Definitions, Headers, Random Number Generator, Recursion
Arrays: Arrays to Functions, Sorting, Searching
Pointers: Operators, Passing Arguments to Functions by Reference, Expressions and Arithmetic, Arrays
Characters and Strings: Character-Handling Library, Input/Output, Search, Memory
Formatted Input/Output: printf, Integers, floating-point numbers, strings, characters, scanf
Structures, Unions, Bit Manipulations and Enumerations
course_objectives: Storage class characteristics for variables, objects and methods and justify the reason(s) for the selection
Solve a variety of programming problems using sound structured, top-down, object-oriented design principles
Use operator overloading and inheritance to minimize reinvention of similar objects
Explain and apply pointers and memory allocation techniques
Explain the difference between (and implications of) reference vs. primitive data types
Design, create and utilize complex classes and their associated objects
Input and output data to and from standard devices and files
Visualize array subscripting as memory offset calculations and explain some of the implications. Represent this visualization in drawings
Utilize fundamental program control structures (sequence, decision, and repetition)
Explain the role of pre-processed code and effectively utilize it
Code efficient sort and search algorithms
Identify the scope of a C++ variable in a program
Demonstrate in a program the use of a method that returns an array
Trace program flow and predict outcomes
method_of_evaluation: Quizzes and exams that measure students’ ability to use programming terminology and explain technical concepts related to program development and implementation in C++.

Practical exams requiring students to trace programming code to predict outcome. For example, a 10-20 line section of code is provided and students must be able to identify how all of the values in all variables are altered by that code and predict the final output as specified in the code.
Projects requiring students to write complete application programs demonstrating effective use of object-oriented principles, methodology and concepts.
minimum_instructional_facilities: Computer lab with networked computers and software to create C++ programming environment
out_of_class_assignments: Design, code and debug multiple C++ programs and objects that demonstrate class objectives
Analyze instructor-assigned pre-coded C++ programs, post analysis comments on the class discussion board.

required: Gaddis, Tony. Starting Out With C++: From Control Structures through Objects. 8th edition. Pearson, 2014.
Paul J. Deitel and Harvey Deitel. C How to Program with the Pearson My Programming Lab component. 8th edition, Pearson, 2015.

exit_skills: Write well-designed C++ code to solve a variety of scientific problems as standalone programs.
Select appropriate storage class characteristics for variables as well as methods.
Solve a variety of programming problems using sound structured, top-down, object-oriented design principles.
Effectively use inheritance to minimize reinvention of similar objects.
Effectively access standard C++ library modules.
Recognize the difference between (and implications of) reference vs. primitive data types.
Design, create and utilize complex classes and objects.
Input and output data to and from standard devices and files.
Visualize array subscripting as memory offset calculations and recognize some of the implications.
Understand and effectively utilize fundamental program control structures.
Understand the relative efficiency of the various sort and search algorithms.
student_learning_outcomes: Decompose problems and design program solutions using flowcharts, pseudocode, models, or other tools.
Properly code applications using the fundamental coding structures: sequence, selection, and loops.
Test and debug applications using debugging tools such as trace execution.
